review_title: “Building the plane while trying to fly it.”
pros:
Brand recognition
Free daily lunches
Free MARTA commute
Within walking distance from MARTA train station
cons:
Like many others reporting: 

Extremely high attrition and turnover (even prior to COVID) from the executive level trickling down to support staff. 
**Draining cycle: New leadership executes poorly planned, shortsighted vision. Another leadership shift occurs. Repeat (every few months).

Toxic metrics obsessed culture - stocks seem to rise yet always in a state of urgency leaving employees feeling burnt out and less and less secure in leadership and their own personal longevity. 

Goal post(s) constantly shift (yes based on market needs but you should already be anticipating those variables and have a wider contingency plan and stronger business execution plan in place).

Expensive, high deductible medical plans (both were 1500+$)

Admin team is also political and clique-based. Smile to your face but will not support you if your procedural team/business solutions don’t align with their own self-serving agendas.

While I’d like to think not everyone in HR is like this, the multiple HR managers I’ve worked with present an overwhelming attitude of arrogance, entitlement, favoritism, politics and close-mindedness
- listening/respecting only those at a certain level of seniority/favoritism
- Making decisions or delegating poorly planned assignments without input or regard of those directly affected - regardless of relative experience and/or insight
- Little to no communication/clarification (and seemingly no desire to) regarding next steps after delegating new initiatives
- Lack of follow through when requesting updates/clarifications
- Lack of accountability even when presented with validating facts. 
- Tells staff a false story to paint a different picture **NO - not one person from HR spoke to me within the last 2 weeks of my resignation despite telling my team members they were unaware of my resignation and supposedly spoke to me 2 days before my last day of employment.

Never in my entire 15+ career have I been told by anyone in an HR dept “it’s not HR’s job to know what it is you do and how you do it”
- HR’s response after the 3rd time I declined additional assigned work after *again* expressing concern over an already overstretched bandwidth while I outlined my current full support duties for my multiple execs as well as proposed multiple solutions

For a globally renowned company with a rich history such as Honeywell, upon hire I was I shocked to discover how underdeveloped and unstable their internal business processes were.

“It’s like flying a plane while trying to build it.”

job_title: Senior Analyst User Experience Design in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: I've never had a "corporate" job before so I was worried that I wouldn't assimilate, but thanks to some great people, supportive managers & some fun projects I can safely say I made the right decision. Those things aside there are a number of other things that make me happy with my move: lateral/upward mobility is one - the company thrives on moving talent across business units; allowing employees to stay engaged and interested. Location is another, the Morris Plains location is beautiful and really makes coming to work everyday easy. Also, upper management gets it, they seem to be making the right moves to pull in & keep talent and to move the company in the right direction.
cons: Honeywell is still growing out of "old" corporate culture. There are times when you're working on something that should seemingly be easy, but you're hit with a roadblock that may take longer than you may be used to due to un-necessarily complex processes and/or a long approval chain. That seems to be heading the way of the dinosaur though - in my brief time here so far, it's already gotten better.

job_title: Senior Advanced Software Engineer in Aguadilla, PR
pros:
*Good Salary (competent salary)
*Good Benefits, all the basics (401K, Health Insurance, Vacations, Holidays, etc)
*Empathy with the employees (Work From Home, During a disaster [Hurricane Maria] they paid us all 3 weeks without working)
*Business Travel (If you do like traveling, in my experience there is an average of one or more business trips a year)
cons:
*Furlough (Sometimes they will inform you that for a week you cannot work and won't get paid for that time. Eg. During covid when all the companies reduced benefits. In my opinion, this is better than other companies reducing the salary by 10-20% to all employees)
*Deadlines are not flexible (During a disaster [Hurricane Maria] we were unable to work by 3 weeks but they did not extend the deadlines by 3 weeks. That implied working overtime, weekends, so basically the 3 weeks paid without working were charged in this way. 
If the person in charge of the planning missed something, the deadline is still not flexible and you need to do that extra tasks without extra time, so it is better to be involved in all the planning of your projects)

review_title: As corporate as it can get
pros: large scale real-time engineering challenges and tasks
cons: too many loosely connected technologies, few too old for today

pros:
Flexible work schedule, we were working from home ever since the pandemic started.
Unlimited PTO
The team I worked with was great! Other program specialists and the engineering teams were very knowledgeable and helpful with anything I needed. Not only were they great to be around professionally but they were great people to be around as well.
cons:
Where do I start..
Upper management was oblivious to what workers really wanted and made life harder based on decisions they made. 
May have unlimited PTO but if you’re on vacation you will still get calls about projects or meetings that people “need” answers to. If you do actually get your time off it takes weeks to get caught up and you end up working OT just to get caught up. 
Speaking of OT, you do get paid OT as straight time but only after you work 8 free hours for the company. OT doesn’t start until after you work 48 hours for the week. 
Upper management doesn’t understand the differences between the two manufacturing facilities in Mason and St. Louis. They try to make policies that fit everyone but instead it usually benefits the Mason office over St. Louis. 
Processes, processes processes. You will get lost in the amount of different processes you have to deal with for every department. Oh and once you get a handle on it they will change them to make them “easier.” But when they change them they’ll still keep the old ones so you’ll have some people using old ones and some people using new ones. Everything got super discombobulated when they started to implement a new scheduling program that is supposed to be the be all end all for schedules, communication, and storage but they didn’t roll it out properly so half the company didn’t know how to use it and when you did learn it broke down every other day. 
Different departments always try to push blame on someone else when something goes wrong. 
Manufacturing schedules were behind by months but Sales continued to sell projects with unrealistic timelines and no one stopped them from doing it. 
Communication with manufacturing was a nightmare because you never knew who to talk to, who was telling the truth or you just never heard back from them. 
Earlier in 2021 we were told we’d be working remotely indefinitely and they’re were discussions about allowing people in the future to work remote or in office but it’d be their choice. Come July we’re told we will be slowly forcing everyone back in the office by September. Out of no where we get an e-mail at the end of July “Everyone is expected back in the office 2 weeks from today with rotating schedules” they went back on their word twice. Management asked what schedules we’d prefer for the rotating schedule or if we’d prefer to just continue to work remote. They didn’t listen to any of the requests and made their own decisions. (Also all this happened directly after the company put out anonymous surveys to all employees regarding their opinion of the company)
Turnover for every department was high (makes you wonder why)
They added responsibilities onto the Program Specialists constantly but didn’t change our pay. 
Changed our title structure with no notice and this caused our salary potential to decrease drastically. 
It used to be 5 steps before you moved into a management role and they changed it to 3 steps but the salary difference didn’t change from step 1-3. 
When they changed it they didn’t audit where people actually were at with their careers and tried to give some people the highest titles with a low salary with no more room for growth. 
I could keep going but you get the point.

review_title: Started my role with great satisfaction and leaving now due to huge dissatisfaction
pros: On the bright side - I have enjoyed my work here for 5 plus years and have contributed for the growth of some of the best BTI and CGI initiatives, great people to work with and that's what makes this company unique, there is plenty of work to wrap up if you are a go getter and are constantly looking for challenges. The brand Honeywell definitely adds value to your work profile. Plenty of opportunity for lateral movements, but not so many for the next level.
cons: On the negative side - Honeywell used to be a great company to work with and grow professionally until 2018. Since mid of 2018 a lot has changed in terms of culture, not being employee friendly, pay cuts, furloughs, no growth, leaders genuinely not interested in your growth anymore, outdated processes and technology and lots more. If you are shareholder then this is company to bet high on, if you are looking for a job then this company may not be a good one in the current scenario.

review_title: Honeywell left a very poor impression with me

Their thinking is it’s their way or the highway, no matter how long you’ve been there and how good of an employee you’ve been. I don’t want or need to be treated that way.

review_title: Fantastic Introductory experience and Awesome Workplace
pros:
-Welcoming team 
-Lots of things to learn
-Best pay in industry
cons: -Have not seeing any for now as there is a proven process to resolve any problem at Honeywell

pros: This company is filled with great co-workers, everyone below middle management has great cohesion and working relationships together. Of all the places I've worked I've enjoyed the people here the most. You'll also get phenomenal exposure to international business due to the range of Honeywell's businesses and office locations.
cons:
While lower staff is truly a cut above the rest, I've never found worse policies and management styles than at Honeywell. This came to a head during the pandemic, there is only a poor strategic vision that's implemented at the top, and sparingly few middle managers who can bridge the gap of understanding at the top, and advocate for their workers below. Honeywell talks a good game about diversity, about invoation, but in reality it's not where you want to be in this new era. Ask any employee behind closed doors, and they'll express deep frustations about being underappreciated, with deadlines expedited at the drop of the hat, no respect for the changing work landscape, and about the new HR mantra of "if you don't like Honeywell's culutre then maybe this isn't the company for you" that has started in the past 6 months.

I ignored people who told me of Honeywell's corporate culture when I first started, I saw an interesting company with above average pay and okay brand recognition. I'm now looking toward leaving, to a new role, with less pay, just to find senior leadership who learns to value me and an HR department that recognizes more than corporate policy.

job_title: Test Software Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I got a 20% raise by moving to Honeywell for essentially the same role at my old company.
cons:
Very old, siloed culture. I was building applications on my own, without anyone to collaborate with, which was extremely suffocating. There was a lot of legacy code and applications that I was replacing, which led to a lot of dull days poring over bad code. There weren't even many people my age, which means that I just felt further isolated.

Also, watch out: "unlimited PTO" actually means you get X weeks, no questions asked; after those X weeks (scaled depending on tenure at the company, like most old benefits packages), your additional hours work against you in performance reviews. I became aware of this after the fact, and I felt like the company was extremely disingenuous in their communication. They wanted to appeal to millennials, without actually giving them what they were advertising.

- First thing that hits you is the Internal politics

Mind you these Big bosses are themselves Indians.

- Honeywell go harping about reporting Conflict of Interest in their every training. However the ground reality is that a Manager happily hires his own family members to his team without any fear. 

- Talk about Diversity, they do not encourage female employees growing beyond a certain position. I have seen many women colleagues complaining about this to me in my tenure at Honeywell

- You can do no real work whole year and yet you can shine in the Appraisal if you show just show the same servile attitude to your Indian managers

- In my case the Manager's ensured my Final settlements are purposely delayed by more than 2 months which I felt highly unprofessional.

review_title: Shaping the Future...on a tight budget
pros: Honeywell middle management is generally flexible, forward thinking, and generally wants to be there / make a difference in their workplace. Honeywell has generally supported grassroots employee resource groups, such as networks for Women in Tech, LGBT, Veterans, Black, Latinx, etc. Growth areas of the company are generally rewarding to be a part of, and there are frequent opportunities for people to work on interesting technology.
cons: Honeywell, at the high levels, employs a hardball culture, and expects to win every short-term negotiation it participates in, whether it is with customers, suppliers, or employees. Stock price and working capital are king, and this guides most short and long term decisions in the company. Expect the quality of your benefits to decline every year, either in monetary value or flexibility. For example, raises were awarded, frozen, and then taken away in 2020. During benefits enrollment, they advertised no increase in premiums...for those who did not see a salary increase. For those who did, they were tagged with a 40% increase. Honeywell had recently increased the company match from 6% or 7%, but revised it to providing in a lump sum at the end of the year, offsetting any annual compounding they would have received.

job_title: Senior Analyst User Experience Design in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: I've never had a "corporate" job before so I was worried that I wouldn't assimilate, but thanks to some great people, supportive managers & some fun projects I can safely say I made the right decision. Those things aside there are a number of other things that make me happy with my move: lateral/upward mobility is one - the company thrives on moving talent across business units; allowing employees to stay engaged and interested. Location is another, the Morris Plains location is beautiful and really makes coming to work everyday easy. Also, upper management gets it, they seem to be making the right moves to pull in & keep talent and to move the company in the right direction.
cons: Honeywell is still growing out of "old" corporate culture. There are times when you're working on something that should seemingly be easy, but you're hit with a roadblock that may take longer than you may be used to due to un-necessarily complex processes and/or a long approval chain. That seems to be heading the way of the dinosaur though - in my brief time here so far, it's already gotten better.

pros: Honeywell is developing a very inclusive and progressive culture

review_title: “Building the plane while trying to fly it.”
pros:
Brand recognition
Free daily lunches
Free MARTA commute
Within walking distance from MARTA train station
cons:
Like many others reporting: 

Extremely high attrition and turnover (even prior to COVID) from the executive level trickling down to support staff. 
**Draining cycle: New leadership executes poorly planned, shortsighted vision. Another leadership shift occurs. Repeat (every few months).

Toxic metrics obsessed culture - stocks seem to rise yet always in a state of urgency leaving employees feeling burnt out and less and less secure in leadership and their own personal longevity. 

Goal post(s) constantly shift (yes based on market needs but you should already be anticipating those variables and have a wider contingency plan and stronger business execution plan in place).

Expensive, high deductible medical plans (both were 1500+$)

Admin team is also political and clique-based. Smile to your face but will not support you if your procedural team/business solutions don’t align with their own self-serving agendas.

While I’d like to think not everyone in HR is like this, the multiple HR managers I’ve worked with present an overwhelming attitude of arrogance, entitlement, favoritism, politics and close-mindedness
- listening/respecting only those at a certain level of seniority/favoritism
- Making decisions or delegating poorly planned assignments without input or regard of those directly affected - regardless of relative experience and/or insight
- Little to no communication/clarification (and seemingly no desire to) regarding next steps after delegating new initiatives
- Lack of follow through when requesting updates/clarifications
- Lack of accountability even when presented with validating facts. 
- Tells staff a false story to paint a different picture **NO - not one person from HR spoke to me within the last 2 weeks of my resignation despite telling my team members they were unaware of my resignation and supposedly spoke to me 2 days before my last day of employment.

Never in my entire 15+ career have I been told by anyone in an HR dept “it’s not HR’s job to know what it is you do and how you do it”
- HR’s response after the 3rd time I declined additional assigned work after *again* expressing concern over an already overstretched bandwidth while I outlined my current full support duties for my multiple execs as well as proposed multiple solutions

For a globally renowned company with a rich history such as Honeywell, upon hire I was I shocked to discover how underdeveloped and unstable their internal business processes were.

“It’s like flying a plane while trying to build it.”

*Empathy with the employees (Work From Home, During a disaster [Hurricane Maria] they paid us all 3 weeks without working)
*Business Travel (If you do like traveling, in my experience there is an average of one or more business trips a year)
cons:
*Furlough (Sometimes they will inform you that for a week you cannot work and won't get paid for that time. Eg. During covid when all the companies reduced benefits. In my opinion, this is better than other companies reducing the salary by 10-20% to all employees)
*Deadlines are not flexible (During a disaster [Hurricane Maria] we were unable to work by 3 weeks but they did not extend the deadlines by 3 weeks. That implied working overtime, weekends, so basically the 3 weeks paid without working were charged in this way. 
If the person in charge of the planning missed something, the deadline is still not flexible and you need to do that extra tasks without extra time, so it is better to be involved in all the planning of your projects)

Upper management was oblivious to what workers really wanted and made life harder based on decisions they made. 
May have unlimited PTO but if you’re on vacation you will still get calls about projects or meetings that people “need” answers to. If you do actually get your time off it takes weeks to get caught up and you end up working OT just to get caught up. 
Speaking of OT, you do get paid OT as straight time but only after you work 8 free hours for the company. OT doesn’t start until after you work 48 hours for the week. 
Upper management doesn’t understand the differences between the two manufacturing facilities in Mason and St. Louis. They try to make policies that fit everyone but instead it usually benefits the Mason office over St. Louis. 
Processes, processes processes. You will get lost in the amount of different processes you have to deal with for every department. Oh and once you get a handle on it they will change them to make them “easier.” But when they change them they’ll still keep the old ones so you’ll have some people using old ones and some people using new ones. Everything got super discombobulated when they started to implement a new scheduling program that is supposed to be the be all end all for schedules, communication, and storage but they didn’t roll it out properly so half the company didn’t know how to use it and when you did learn it broke down every other day. 
Different departments always try to push blame on someone else when something goes wrong. 
Manufacturing schedules were behind by months but Sales continued to sell projects with unrealistic timelines and no one stopped them from doing it. 
Communication with manufacturing was a nightmare because you never knew who to talk to, who was telling the truth or you just never heard back from them. 
Earlier in 2021 we were told we’d be working remotely indefinitely and they’re were discussions about allowing people in the future to work remote or in office but it’d be their choice. Come July we’re told we will be slowly forcing everyone back in the office by September. Out of no where we get an e-mail at the end of July “Everyone is expected back in the office 2 weeks from today with rotating schedules” they went back on their word twice. Management asked what schedules we’d prefer for the rotating schedule or if we’d prefer to just continue to work remote. They didn’t listen to any of the requests and made their own decisions. (Also all this happened directly after the company put out anonymous surveys to all employees regarding their opinion of the company)
Turnover for every department was high (makes you wonder why)
They added responsibilities onto the Program Specialists constantly but didn’t change our pay. 
Changed our title structure with no notice and this caused our salary potential to decrease drastically. 
It used to be 5 steps before you moved into a management role and they changed it to 3 steps but the salary difference didn’t change from step 1-3. 
When they changed it they didn’t audit where people actually were at with their careers and tried to give some people the highest titles with a low salary with no more room for growth. 
I could keep going but you get the point.

pros: This company is filled with great co-workers, everyone below middle management has great cohesion and working relationships together. Of all the places I've worked I've enjoyed the people here the most. You'll also get phenomenal exposure to international business due to the range of Honeywell's businesses and office locations.
cons:
While lower staff is truly a cut above the rest, I've never found worse policies and management styles than at Honeywell. This came to a head during the pandemic, there is only a poor strategic vision that's implemented at the top, and sparingly few middle managers who can bridge the gap of understanding at the top, and advocate for their workers below. Honeywell talks a good game about diversity, about invoation, but in reality it's not where you want to be in this new era. Ask any employee behind closed doors, and they'll express deep frustations about being underappreciated, with deadlines expedited at the drop of the hat, no respect for the changing work landscape, and about the new HR mantra of "if you don't like Honeywell's culutre then maybe this isn't the company for you" that has started in the past 6 months.

I ignored people who told me of Honeywell's corporate culture when I first started, I saw an interesting company with above average pay and okay brand recognition. I'm now looking toward leaving, to a new role, with less pay, just to find senior leadership who learns to value me and an HR department that recognizes more than corporate policy.

job_title: Test Software Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I got a 20% raise by moving to Honeywell for essentially the same role at my old company.
cons:
Very old, siloed culture. I was building applications on my own, without anyone to collaborate with, which was extremely suffocating. There was a lot of legacy code and applications that I was replacing, which led to a lot of dull days poring over bad code. There weren't even many people my age, which means that I just felt further isolated.

Also, watch out: "unlimited PTO" actually means you get X weeks, no questions asked; after those X weeks (scaled depending on tenure at the company, like most old benefits packages), your additional hours work against you in performance reviews. I became aware of this after the fact, and I felt like the company was extremely disingenuous in their communication. They wanted to appeal to millennials, without actually giving them what they were advertising.

job_title: Advanced Software Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Products are cool to work on. Coworkers are fun to work with. Low levels of management (director and below) are pretty good.
cons: The company is run via metric hacking. The one being focused on at the moment is "working capital". Obviously when you over-simplify running a business to focus on a single thing, you create inappropriate incentives and you get unexpected consequences. Honeywell has a retention issue with anyone who has mobility (no kids in school, recent grad, etc). This is largely because of a lack of career advancement. Career advancement means promotions, promotions mean increased costs (and increased productivity), but the executive managers have gone down a path that requires them to continue to cut costs to keep the company appearing successful.

job_title: Senior Advanced Software Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
- Trainings and access to popular Technical courses like Coursera, Pluralsight etc.
- Cab facilities 
- You get to work on the latest technological stack 
- Very good streamlined process when it comes to onboarding, HR, IP related 
- Handsome monetary reward if you file patents
cons:
- First thing that hits you is the Internal politics 

- Majority of the SW Engineering Managers based in India are highly incapable to and never standup with their team when it comes dealing with the Big bosses who sit with an air of superiority in the US and treat the Indian employees with utmost disdain and zero respect. Mind you these Big bosses are themselves Indians.

- Honeywell go harping about reporting Conflict of Interest in their every training. However the ground reality is that a Manager happily hires his own family members to his team without any fear. 

- Talk about Diversity, they do not encourage female employees growing beyond a certain position. I have seen many women colleagues complaining about this to me in my tenure at Honeywell

- You can do no real work whole year and yet you can shine in the Appraisal if you show just show the same servile attitude to your Indian managers

- In my case the Manager's ensured my Final settlements are purposely delayed by more than 2 months which I felt highly unprofessional.

Decent job for entry level technicians,
401k with 80% match for first 8% of your pay,
2 weeks vacation and 56 hours paid sick leave,
Health, Vision and dental
Company paid life insurance for 4x your salary
cons:
Annual raises rarely happen and when they do, they don’t even come close to the rate of inflation. So the longer you work for them, the less you make.
It’s impossible to communicate issues with supervisors as they are overworked and don’t actually supervise anyone. And when you do, they are never resolved.
The company has stripped away all of the perks including all company functions and as a result, moral is very low.
They have gone from caring about quality to only caring about quantity. Quality issues are ignored.
